HRLR201.name: Human Capital and Society
HRLR201.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
HRLR201.description: Human capital and society from cultural, organizational, and worker perspectives. Interdisciplinary and professional aspects of human resources and labor relations.

HRLR211.name: Introduction to Organizational Leadership
HRLR211.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HRLR211.description: Leadership theories and research. Sources of power. Influence tactics.

HRLR212.name: Career Management
HRLR212.description: Career development. Career self-assessment, occupational opportunities, changing global world of work, social networking, written communication, job interviews, the first job, career planning and decision making.

HRLR311.name: Applied Organizational Leadership
HRLR311.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HRLR311.description: Leadership skill development. Strategic choices for organizations.

HRLR313.name: Employment Relations
HRLR313.description: Labor relations, collective bargaining involving unions, dispute resolution, and arbitration.

HRLR314.name: Legal Environment of Work
HRLR314.description: Legal rights of workers and responsibilities of employers affecting safety, nondiscrimination, wages, hours & benefits, collective action and unionization.

HRLR315.name: Research Methods and Analysis
HRLR315.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HRLR315.description: Social science research methodology and analysis techniques as applied to human capital issues.

HRLR316.name: Economics of Human Capital
HRLR316.description: Economic and strategic aspects of human capital analysis and development in organizations.

HRLR401.name: Income Inequality
HRLR401.description: Explanations for income inequality, including disparities based on gender, race and class. Solutions for income inequality.

HRLR410.name: Voice and Democracy at Work
HRLR410.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HRLR410.description: Collective action by workers. Worker voice and democracy within and outside of work organizations. Historical and current examples.

HRLR414.name: Legal Standards in a Global Workplace
HRLR414.description: Workers’ rights as human rights in developed and developing countries. Private, national, and international standards.

HRLR420.name: Comparative Human Capital Systems
HRLR420.description: Institutional networks and practices in human capital systems in selected countries. Labor and employment laws, employment relations, and human resources practices.

HRLR465.name: Capstone in Human Capital and Society
HRLR465.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HRLR465.description: Comparative and international employment relations. Contemporary labor market trends and issues. High performance work systems and organizational effectiveness. Diverse stakeholders and worker outcomes.
HRLR465.prerequisite: (HRLR 201 and HRLR 315 and HRLR 313 and HRLR 314 and (HRLR 410 or concurrently)) and completion of Tier I writing requirement

HRLR494.name: Undergraduate Research in Human Capital and Society
HRLR494.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
HRLR494.description: Faculty-guided undergraduate research in disciplines encompassed in human capital and society.
HRLR494.restrictions: Open to undergraduate students in the College of Social Science or approval of school.

HRLR809.name: Economics of Human Resources
HRLR809.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HRLR809.description: Labor market behavior, structures, factors of supply and demand, and labor market analysis as related to human resources.
HRLR809.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the School of Human Resources and Labor Relations or approval of school.

HRLR813.name: Organizational Behavior for Human Resources and Labor Relations
HRLR813.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HRLR813.description: Behavioral science knowledge at micro- and macro- levels. Individual, group and organizational functioning in human resources and labor relations settings.
HRLR813.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the School of Human Resources and Labor Relations or approval of school.

HRLR816.name: Organizational Development and Change
HRLR816.description: General systems and organizational behavior theories in organizational development and change.
HRLR816.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the School of Human Resources and Labor Relations or approval of school.

HRLR817.name: High Performance Work Systems
HRLR817.description: History, evolution, and approaches to design and implement effective High Performance Work Systems across diverse organizational environments.
HRLR817.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the School of Human Resources and Labor Relations or approval of school.

HRLR818.name: Leadership
HRLR818.description: Leadership theories relevant to human resources.
HRLR818.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the School of Human Resources and Labor Relations or approval of school.

HRLR819.name: Negotiation and Conflict Resolution
HRLR819.description: Negotiation and conflict resolution in the employment relationship. Use of experiential simulations to develop bargaining styles and interpersonal process skills.
HRLR819.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the School of Human Resources and Labor Relations or approval of school.

HRLR820.name: Human Resource Practices and Decisions
HRLR820.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HRLR820.description: Human resource strategy, planning, staffing, performance management, training and development, rewards, safety and health. Functions of human resources at the strategic, managerial and operational levels of the organization.
HRLR820.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the School of Human Resources and Labor Relations or approval of school.

HRLR821.name: Talent Acquisition and Deployment
HRLR821.description: Process by which organizations acquire, retain, and deploy the organization’s workforce. Planning, recruiting, selecting, placing, and managing turnover and evaluation.
HRLR821.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the School of Human Resources and Labor Relations or approval of school.

HRLR822.name: Training and Development
HRLR822.description: Human resource training and development. Design, administration needs assessment, delivery, evaluation.
HRLR822.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the School of Human Resources and Labor Relations or approval of school.

HRLR825.name: Compensation
HRLR825.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HRLR825.description: Concepts, principles, theories, tools and techniques in the design and administration of employee compensation systems. Strategic, managerial, and operational considerations and roles in compensation system design.
HRLR825.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the School of Human Resources and Labor Relations or approval of school.

HRLR832.name: Quantitative Methods for Human Resources Analyses
HRLR832.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HRLR832.description: Evaluation, use, and interpretation of data for human resources and labor relations. Multivariate statistical analysis techniques and application to organizational situations.
HRLR832.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the School of Human Resources and Labor Relations or approval of school.

HRLR854.name: Comparative Employment Relations
HRLR854.description: Institutional networks of industrial relations and human resource systems in various countries.
HRLR854.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the School of Human Resources and Labor Relations or approval of school.

HRLR855.name: International Human Resources
HRLR855.description: Role and functions of human resources in global organizations.
HRLR855.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the School of Human Resources and Labor Relations or approval of school.

HRLR858.name: Collective Bargaining
HRLR858.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HRLR858.description: Theory and practice of collective bargaining. Wages, benefits, seniority, grievances, arbitration, and labor-management committees. Legal, economic, technological, and historical contexts.
HRLR858.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the School of Human Resources and Labor Relations or approval of school.

HRLR859.name: Study Abroad in Human Resources and Labor Relations
HRLR859.description: International dimensions of human resources and labor relations.
HRLR859.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the School of Human Resources and Labor Relations or approval of school.

HRLR863.name: Labor Law
HRLR863.description: Legal framework for contract negotiations and administration. National Labor Relations Act as amended. Right to organize and undertake concerted activity. Strikes and lockouts. Unfair labor practices.
HRLR863.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the School of Human Resources and Labor Relations or approval of school.

HRLR865.name: Grievance Administration and Arbitration
HRLR865.description: Grievance procedure and arbitration as the terminal step in the grievance process under collective bargaining, grievance procedures in union and non-union employment settings.
HRLR865.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the School of Human Resources and Labor Relations or approval of school.

HRLR868.name: Employment Law
HRLR868.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HRLR868.description: Legal regulation of the relationship between and employers and individual employees. Concepts, legislation, and application of human resource law.
HRLR868.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the School of Human Resources and Labor Relations or approval of school.

HRLR871.name: Human Resource and Firm Performance
HRLR871.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HRLR871.description: Foundations of investments in human resources and effects on firm performance.
HRLR871.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the School of Human Resources and Labor Relations or approval of school.

HRLR872.name: Human Resources Strategy
HRLR872.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HRLR872.description: Human resources as a source of competitive advantage. Role of human resource systems and functions in implementing organizational strategy.
HRLR872.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the School of Human Resources and Labor Relations or approval of school.

HRLR890.name: Independent Study in Human Resources and Labor Relations
HRLR890.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
HRLR890.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the School of Human Resources and Labor Relations or approval of school.

HRLR891.name: Special Topics in Human Resources and Labor Relations
HRLR891.description: Special topics in collective bargaining, human resources, employment, and training.
HRLR891.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the School of Human Resources and Labor Relations or approval of school.

HRLR899.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
HRLR899.restrictions: Open to students in the School of Human Resources and Labor Relations. Approval of school.

HRLR990.description: Individual readings under faculty guidance for doctoral students.
HRLR990.restrictions: Open to doctoral students in the School of Human Resources and Labor Relations. Approval of school.

HRLR991A.description: Theoretical perspectives and foundations for human resource management
HRLR991A.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the School of Human Resources and Labor Relations or approval of school.

HRLR991B.description: Theoretical perspectives and foundations for labor and employment relations.
HRLR991B.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the School of Human Resources and Labor Relations or approval of school.

HRLR992B.description: Research and policy analysis of selected topics in labor and employment relations.
HRLR992B.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the School of Human Resources and Labor Relations or approval of school.
